content:
Dinesh Ch is working on adding typing indicators for streams messages (#17040) and read receipts (#15032).

I'd like to start a conversation about what we want on the privacy side of these features. I think in line with our general privacy-friendly model, we probably want to allow users to disable sharing of read receipts and typing notifications for their account. Thoughts?

I can imagine we would add those adjacent to this existing privacy-related setting:
image.png

Agreed that we should have a setting. Especially for read receipts... Typing notifications seem less important, in that if you actually send the message, it doesn't provide a huge amount of additional information. But probably worth doing regardless.

I think there's a few questions:

  • Do we want just on/off, or also a "On for PMs, not for stream messages" additional state?
  • What do we want to call this setting?
  • For typing notifications, the semantics are clear if the setting is disabled; you just don't send anything.
  • For "who has read this message", which we're currently for data synchronization scaling planning to only offer on explicit request (i.e. you click something to fetch and see it, not it appears by default, though we could do that for groups up to 20 or so if we wanted to). We might need to decide whether to indicate who has disabled the setting, to avoid it looking like a bug. ("How did Tim reply to this message if he hasn't seen it?")

Tim Abbott said:

I can imagine we would add those adjacent to this existing privacy-related setting:
image.png

That makes sense to me.

Though on a related topic, should we move this section of the menu? It's currently under Notifications, which I generally interpret as, "how I get notifed about things", not "how other users get notifed about what I do". Perhaps You account is a better place for it?

I don't think that'd be an improvement; "Your account" has a highly variable amount of custom profile fields that makes it hard to place other things on it. And currently everything on that page is part of your profile, whereas these settings are not.

I agree that "notifications" is a pretty surprising place to find these settings, or that existing presence setting. Surprising enough that if there was a setting like this that defaulted to on (less private), and I wanted to turn off (more private), I could easily see feeling deceived about it.

"Your account" seems like a less bad place than that -- not like deceptively hiding anything, at least. But still not a good fit.
Potentially with three of these settings they could get a new section, named like "Privacy".
Or the API key could move there (from "Your Account"), and make the name like "Privacy & Security".

Greg Price said:

Or the API key could move there (from "Your Account"), and make the name like "Privacy & Security".

Yeah, I think that last proposal makes the most sense to me as a plan. Maybe "Security & privacy" would be the more natural name.
Privacy & Security sounds more normal to me -- not sure why.
I suspect if we look at 5 other products, they're largely put "security" first of those two if they're listed together.

Twitter has "Settings and privacy" and within that "Privacy and safety". Discord also does "Privacy and safety". Checking half a dozen or so other sites didn't find anybody else that put anything even that similar together, so who knows.

We might need to decide whether to indicate who has disabled the setting, to avoid it looking like a bug. ("How did Tim reply to this message if he hasn't seen it?"

I'm not sure what a good UI for this would be when a bunch of people disable the setting being in a stream with a lot of subscribers if we want them to be displayed in the UI element(which should perhaps look something like typeahead list with scroll) where we show "read by these users" list. Perhaps a note at the bottom of list saying something like "we don't show read indicators for people who've disabled them" would be good?

There's also another question: If a user disables the feature, should we also disable all incoming notifications too? I didn't check what others like slack do but Whatsapp doesn't show others' read indicators if you've disabled sharing your read data.

For "who has read this message", which we're currently for data synchronization scaling planning to only offer on explicit request (i.e. you click something to fetch and see it, not it appears by default, ...

Also, any ideas on what this 'something' should be? I think It can be an icon like 'add emoji reaction' button not sure what would be a good fit. Would the eye icon we show in compose area to see message preview work for this?
Yeah, potentially that sort of generic notice makes sense.

Dinesh Ch said:

There's also another question: If a user disables the feature, should we also disable all incoming notifications too? I didn't check what others like slack do but Whatsapp doesn't show others' read indicators if you've disabled sharing your read data.

I don't think we need to do that, but that's a good point: We should find the Help Center pages for a few other chat products' "read indicators" features and any privacy settings around them.
I don't have a great idea for iconology, but I think a click handler for hovering the timestamp is a valid possibility.
will check out other chat products for that.

Tim Abbott said:

I don't have a great idea for iconology, but I think a click handler for hovering the timestamp is a valid possibility.

My thinking about hovering a timestamp as not a great idea is that there's no way we can convey "zulip supports read indicators and you can hover over the timestamp to see who read your message" from the UI but people might discover that accidentally hovering over it if they didn't know.
How about adding it to the three-dot menu?
Maybe we can add an option in the message ellipsis (three-dot) menu which opens a modal showing users who have read the message.

That feels like more work to the user for a feature that they'll be using often. Imagine having to click three dots and click choose emoji picker every time you want to react to a message with an emoji.
Yes, a modal would be better if we decide for it to be an option in three-dots.

We could also have the read-by users' list be similar to the UI of the user suggestions list we show on trying to do @ mentions with a scroll but that will probably look odd if we are opening it from the three-dots menu but may be fine if we display it with hover on timestamp.

Alya Abbott said:

How about adding it to the three-dot menu?

I think a popover accessed via the 3-dots menu is probably fine for an initial version. I'm not certain that this will be a popular enough feature to justify something else.

We're talking about the UI for seeing read receipts, right?

I'd be concerned about having that feature be hard to discover so that it feels hidden, in any org where it's enabled. That seems like a recipe for people to feel like their privacy was violated.

In chat products I've used where read receipts are present (that I know of!), they're visible all the time.

The ones I can think of are all basically SMS-style: FB Messenger, WhatsApp, IIRC Signal, plus the SMS-but-fancier-where-possible system apps like iMessage.

Hmm, that's a fair point.

It's seems fairly useful for PMs, but I'd be pretty worried about it just being clutter for stream messages. I suppose we could just have the feature for PMs and make it always-visible there.
That seems like a reasonable plan, certainly for an initial version.

Looking back at #15032, the person filing that issue was specifically interested in read receipts on @-mentions, presumably mainly in streams. They included this screenshot of what that apparently looks like in Flowdock:
image.png

Which is an interesting UI idea. The receipt is indicated right there on the @-mention box.

That issue also links to a previous issue thread #3618. That thread got kind of chaotic with discussion of a bounty, but I think at least some people there are definitely hoping to get the feature in stream threads.

One of them specifically describes the kind of UI I've seen for this in several apps that seems to work well:

We are moving from Google Hangouts to Zulip and would love to see something along these lines. In Hangouts, there are little floating avatars for each user that indicates where the message stream was at when they last viewed it.

One possible direction could be:

  • find a UI that makes it always visible and works well for a small number of users -- like take that classic UI and adapt it somehow to our world of interleaved views and non-consecutive unreads
  • then have the feature apply only when the number of subscribed users is small enough, both in streams and PMs
  • plus also do something specifically for @-mentions, like in the screenshot above.

Yeah... I guess I'd start with something like:

  1. 1:1 PMs: A checkmark to indicate it's been read.
  2. Group PMs: Think about the icons for everyone has read/some people have read. Hovering over the icon would display who has read the message.
  3. @mentions (as described above)

And then if you really care about who has read your stream message, you just need to @mention them. Which you can do with @_ if you don't want to bother them.
I don't think this feature as an "always-visible" widget makes sense for streams with more than 20 or so users; beyond that you get quadratic scaling issues.

Thanks for all your thoughtful insights and suggestions!

Tim Abbott said:

I don't think this feature as an "always-visible" widget makes sense for streams with more than 20 or so users; beyond that you get quadratic scaling issues.

I guess you're referring to only the idea of showing all users who read a particular message in a stream but not to just have them for @ mentions. Could you confirm? I think Alya Abbott's suggestion of making it a feature for only PMs and mentions makes sense with the justification of if someone cares about a particular person reading their message, they can @mention them.

Quadratic scaling issues of sending read notification to all members in the stream reading the message to all others wouldn't be there as we only send that data to all for the very few(one or two) users mentioned. It might be an issue for large group PMs but ideally one would make a private stream instead of a large group PM.

In terms of implementation, it can be similar to typing indicators along with a write to DB(perhaps asynchronously, if it takes time) where

  • a request is sent to /json/read_message(or some better name :) with user_id and message id when mentioned users/users involved in PMs read the message
  • This data gets forwarded through our events system to the users subscribed to stream/ user(s) in (group)PM which will be used render read indicator
  • The above would also trigger a write to the database which can be used to load read indicators when the app is first opened.

Does it make sense?

Going through #3618 again, Use case of read indicators mostly seem to be concerning a single person reading the message which I kind of inferred from [this comment] saying:

Read receipts enable the message sender to stop thinking about a problem, and move on. With distributed teams, we frequently need to know "Does person X know about this problem?" When we have a read receipt, we can put our mind at ease, and move on. If too much time goes by and they have not read the message, we have to make other plans to solve problems.

But another user who seems to be concerned about many users reading their message has a workaround:

Read receipts enable the message sender to stop thinking about a problem, and move on. With distributed teams, we frequently need to know "Does person X know about this problem?" When we have a read receipt, we can put our mind at ease, and move on. If too much time goes by and they have not read the message, we have to make other plans to solve problems.

But probably it's a rare case that they want to know if everyone read their message.

Thinking of the second user's comment above and quadratic scaling issue Tim mentioned, it probably makes sense to only show read indicators to the author of the message. I'm not sure if everyone would be happy with this option but I've seen WhatsApp do that and perhaps signal too does that?

Tim Abbott said:

I don't think this feature as an "always-visible" widget makes sense for streams with more than 20 or so users; beyond that you get quadratic scaling issues.

Yes. I think that's not actually the limiting factor, though, because 20 or so users is already past the limit at which it stops making much sense from a product or UI perspective.

Alya Abbott said:

Yeah... I guess I'd start with something like:

  1. 1:1 PMs: A checkmark to indicate it's been read.
  2. Group PMs: Think about the icons for everyone has read/some people have read. Hovering over the icon would display who has read the message.
  3. @mentions (as described above)

And then if you really care about who has read your stream message, you just need to @mention them. Which you can do with @_ if you don't want to bother them.

This sounds like a good plan to try.

Group PMs: Think about the icons for everyone has read/some people have read. Hovering over the icon would display who has read the message.

Yeah, that's an interesting idea for how to keep down the amount of visual clutter when you aren't paying attention to this feature.

One design direction for those icons could be like "checkmark in unfilled circle" for "some people have read", and then "checkmark in filled circle" for "everyone has read". I feel like that reasonably clearly conveys an order of progression -- especially once you've seen it progress through those stages a few times. (FB Messenger uses these for IIUC "trying to send message" and "message reached server but nobody's read it yet", and then shows little recipient avatars for when the message has been read.)

1:1 PMs: A checkmark to indicate it's been read.

I think it would actually help a lot if we can keep the visuals as similar as possible between 1:1 PMs and group PMs -- that'd help make it feel like one coherent system, and help people figure out how things work because the same patterns get reinforced in each context.
how do we distinguish "turned off sending read receipts" with "unread"? i think it's important to get that right.
also, how will this interact with "mark as read" when we offer that?

Good questions but I'm not certain what the right solutions are.
For the first, maybe we can just show it as unread in case of group pms and show some sort of notification saying some people might've turned of this feature and in case of mentions and PMs we can probably show some sort of visual indicators conveying that they have it turned off.

For the second, it probably makes sense to consider it as read and show read receipts. Additionally, we can show an alert for the first time a user uses "mark as read" saying that this will be considered as read and shown to other users.

Dinesh Ch said:

will check out other chat products for that.

Looks like slack, rocket.chat, and discord doesn't provide read indicators. And discord doesn't seem to provide any option to turn off typing indicators.

Alya Abbott said:

Yeah... I guess I'd start with something like:

  1. 1:1 PMs: A checkmark to indicate it's been read.
  2. Group PMs: Think about the icons for everyone has read/some people have read. Hovering over the icon would display who has read the message.
  3. @mentions (as described above)

And then if you really care about who has read your stream message, you just need to @mention them. Which you can do with @_ if you don't want to bother them.

I started working in this direction. Where would be a good place to have the checkmark? Is it a good idea to have it beside the timestamp?

A few thoughts on this:

  • There should be a org-wide setting as to whether this is enabled, which defaults to off, since many people find read receipts creepy/are frustrated when they're added to a app that didn't have them before.
  • We should consider which of the three types of read receipts people most want, along with the maintenance burden of each one (particularly, the CSS for the @mention read receipts seems sort of complex, although perhaps worth it)
  • The setting for showing read receipts and sending read receipts should be the same. This is quite standard (I can't think of an app that doesn't do it this way), and it feels sort of creepy for someone to see read receipts but not send them.
We should also probably have it so that Notification Bot announce when read receipts are turned on/off, and links to the help page describing how they work, so that people know when that happens.
Makes sense to me. We should probably aim to get those settings part too done before adding this feature.

Where would be a good place to have the checkmark? Is it a good idea to have it beside the timestamp?

Tried it beside the timestamp temporarily.. Realised that having a checkmark in PMs will make the message list inconsistent with a few message boxes having checkmark while others(i.e user received messages) don't. Any ideas on how to make this look less odd?

Dinesh Ch said:

Realised that having a checkmark in PMs will make the message list inconsistent with a few message boxes having checkmark while others(i.e user received messages) don't. Any ideas on how to make this look less odd?

I'd try looking at some other apps to see how they handle this. Signal is one that has a setting for read receipts (and it works the same way Wesley described.)

FWIW, I think "read receipts" with data synchronization and a WhatsApp-style UI is a lot of work, and likely not an investment that make sense at this time. The real-time synchronization piece is similar to typing notifications and not too complicated, but we also need to be able to efficiently return the set of users who have read messages in our API requests to fetch 1000 messages of history, and that will look like an additional copy of the Emoji Reactions feature (the issue has notes on a design for that piece).

If we want to have a privacy setting and the simpler "You can get the information with a click if you need" approach, which at least some users on the issue thought would solve their problem, that's a pretty small project, probably 10x less work in Zulip than a WhatsApp-style UI where the "read receipts" status is immediately visible.

I would be very concerned about any design where it's possible for a user to discover the feature has been operating invisibly for them all along. As I said above:

Greg Price said:

I'd be concerned about having that feature be hard to discover so that it feels hidden, in any org where it's enabled. That seems like a recipe for people to feel like their privacy was violated.

One way to address that would be to give it a UI that's always visible.

Another possible way would be to make it a per-user opt-in, regardless of org settings. I feel like people who want to use the feature would not find that very satisfying, though.

Greg Price said:

I'd try looking at some other apps to see how they handle this. Signal is one that has a setting for read receipts (and it works the same way Wesley described.)

Their messages view has a different model where the user received messages float on the left and sent on the right. So, the read indicators need to be shown for the right side ones only which give a consistent look for all the right ones. But our messages view is different and having read indicator(checkmark) for only sent messages in our case makes the UI odd. So I think there isn't much we can take from Signal or similar apps in terms of UI. Are there professional chat tools like ours offering read indicators? (Slack and rocket chat doesn't seem to provide this)

The real-time synchronization piece is similar to typing notifications and not too complicated, but we also need to be able to efficiently return the set of users who have read messages in our API requests to fetch 1000 messages of history, and that will look like an additional copy of the Emoji Reactions feature (the issue has notes on a design for that piece).

Having figured the real-time synchronization part, I'm currently trying this which seems a bit complex. Thought it wouldn't require changes in models.py until I read those notes again. so, It would be inefficient without an extra table/ an entry in Message. Will look at Reactions and SubMessage as you suggested there.

If we want to have a privacy setting and the simpler "You can get the information with a click if you need" approach, which at least some users on the issue thought would solve their problem, that's a pretty small project, probably 10x less work in Zulip than a WhatsApp-style UI where the "read receipts" status is immediately visible.

Yes, that feels much better especially after me noticing that having a checkmark(or a read indicator in any form) for some messages makes the message view UI odd. And yes, Greg Price's concern makes sense and I agree with that.

Greg Price said:

One way to address that would be to give it a UI that's always visible.

Another possible way would be to make it a per-user opt-in, regardless of org settings. I feel like people who want to use the feature would not find that very satisfying, though.

Sounds good but we might need to hide that for a received message in PMs and that might look odd. Maybe we should look for a different UI for PMs but it isn't probably ideal to have it different for streams and PMs.

How about something like this:
An icon visible only on hover which can be clicked to show users who read the message just like the star message option. In terms of settings:

  • This defaults to off for every realm.
  • And an opt-out feature for users which is accessible when the realm level setting is on. (An opt-in feature will make the org admins less happy because they'll have to ask everyone to turn it on and it might get us people asking for it to be turned on by default)

When read indicators are enabled in the realm, the notification bot announces that this setting is on and can be disabled on a per-person basis in the settings menu.

This helps us eliminate the issues with UI inconsistencies in trying to implement the WhatsApp kind of UI. It might seem a bit invisible but easily discoverable and the notification bot announcement would definitely help. And also less complicated in terms of implementation with some users agreeing that a 'click to get read-by users' UI would work for them as Tim mentioned.

Hey. I was directed here. :) I think that most users are looking for something very simple and "visual". Take a look at how Rocket.Chat doest. Basically a small indicator of "Received" and "Read" is ideal. Maybe we can have two levels of "Privacy": 1) no read receipts; 2) read receipts.

@Razvan Rosca When you've used a feature like this in Rocket.Chat, do you mostly use it

  • in direct messages with one person;
  • in direct messages with several people at once;
  • or in channels?

I ask partly because just in general it's useful to us to understand in detail the use cases different people have for a feature like this, and partly because:

Basically a small indicator of "Received" and "Read" is ideal.

I've seen a design like this in various apps for 1:1 conversations, and it can work well; but it seems like it breaks down once there are several people involved. (What would it show when one person's read the message, another has received it but not read, and a third hasn't yet received it?)

Dinesh Ch said:

How about something like this:
An icon visible only on hover which can be clicked to show users who read the message just like the star message option.

Interesting idea! That could work as a way to make it discoverable enough that people don't feel like it was going on behind their backs.

When read indicators are enabled in the realm, the notification bot announces that this setting is on and can be disabled on a per-person basis in the settings menu.

Yeah, this is good. Though I expect the much more common case will be that it's already enabled when the user joins the org -- so we should think about how to communicate it at that point too.

I second this. It's functionality we used in Rocket Chat with our group also, and it would be good to see here in Zulip now that we're using that.

In RC we used in channel messages, say #general it was great to see who had read your note with something time critical like organising a meeting, etc.

An icon visible only on hover which can be clicked to show users who read the message just like the star message option.

That seems reasonable to me... It's not hard to discover, but doesn't clutter things too much for the vast majority of situations when you aren't actively wondering whether your message has been read or not.

Okay, I'll start working towards that.

Yes, we should be a bit concerned about new users joining an org that has it already enabled. Perhaps adding it to the onboarding tutorial/ welcome bot messages is a fine idea but we'd ideally want to keep it minimal. Since we'd only show it for orgs with read receipts enabled, it is OK I think.

And if we are doing something like quill as discussed in #design > Welcome Bot onboarding flow, which is a great improvement to the onboarding experience, we can be almost certain that no one will miss existence of read receipts by adding a short message(conditionally) about them.

(I have a very basic prototype of the earlier discussed real-time sync one. Just posting a link incase it'd be helpful in the future in any way.)

Greg Price said:

Razvan Rosca When you've used a feature like this in Rocket.Chat, do you mostly use it

  • in direct messages with one person;
  • in direct messages with several people at once;
  • or in channels?

1) Direct messages: exactly like WhatsApp treats it, clean and simple. This is, in my opinion, my main reason for people asking for this. If I write something to my colleague, I need to know if he received my message and if he read it, because if he didn't I should contact somebody else.
2) Direct messages with several people. I don't usually do group DMs, because we have channels so why would I group DM?
3) In channels: yes, it's important to know how many colleagues read the very important announcement. In a workplace environment you shouldn't be worried about "your boss knowing if you read the message". It's your boss, or colleague, they should know if you read it or not, because your own actions influence others as well.

Interesting, thanks Razvan Rosca.

When you use it in channels, what does it look like there? There are a lot of people who might or might not have read and/or received the message, so just a small indicator of "Received" or "Read" doesn't seem like enough.

If I may chime in here, in Rocket Chat, it looked like this. Click on the ... menu and it's under "info."

RocketChat_Read-info-sc.m4v

That's very helpful, thanks @eruqalk !

So there's a three-dots menu on the message, rather like ours.

One of the options is "Info".

That pops up a little modal which has a list of people who've read the message, with the timestamps when they read it.
Thanks Razvan Rosca and eruqalk! To be clear, do those green ticks on right in channels mean the message is read by everyone?
Sorry @Dinesh Ch I'm not sure what you mean... what green ticks are you talking about?
Oh, they're kinda blue. these ticks I mean: image.png

I'm thinking of using tippyjs (like we're doing for popovers that is being discussed at #frontend > popovers - tippy ) to show users who read the message on clicking the icon.

So it'd look like a popover with a scroll functionality if there are many people.

Does it make sense?
Also, does anyone have ideas on what the icon should be? For now, I'll go with some text like read by.

Dinesh Ch said:

Thanks Razvan Rosca and eruqalk! To be clear, do those green ticks on right in channels mean the message is read by everyone?

Ah. Yes, it appears those blue ticks mean the message has been read by everyone in the Rocket Chat channel.

But if you ask me, maybe that's visual clutter? To my mind, it's much more helpful to have an option in the ... menu that shows you who has read the message, if you're interested in that information for a specific message. I'm thinking of instances where there are hundreds of users---most often messages are not going to be read by everyone for a very long time (and in some cases, at all) and so a tick indicator like that isn't particularly helpful, but that's my 2c...

Oh, okay, thanks for clarifying.

Yes, I share the same views about those ticks being visual clutter :smile:

Another thing I've been pondering about is whether it's required to let a user see another user's sent messages' read-by-users data. I see rocket chat is allowing that but I'm not aware of any others like WhatsApp, signal showing that.

@Jore as a user, do you find it useful?

Dinesh Ch said:

Also, does anyone have ideas on what the icon should be? For now, I'll go with some text like read by.

A few icon types I see are:

  1. Open envelope, like envelope
  2. Dialog box with a check like dialog
  3. Double checkmarks double-check
  4. Generic box with a checkmark. box-check

Do we use envelopes or dialog icons anywhere to refer to messages? If not, perhaps a variant of (3) or (4) is best...
envelope = PM usually for us, I think?
Hmm, https://fontawesome.com/v4.7/icon/book is another natural direction for "read".
Yeah, books feel like not the right analogy for messages to me, but it's an option.
I like the check-mark direction.

Hi all, I think checkmarks would be good too. As for users being able to see other users' read messages info, for our use-case that would be a wanted behaviour, yes. The idea is anyone being able to gauge other people's engagement if they're not writing much, if necessary, is part of what makes read receipts useful (for us at least)... Hope that's helpful!

With double ticks, there's a slight risk of conveying that message is read by everyone. (2) and (4) makes more sense to me. (4) with a few horizontal lines(resembling list) might be perfect to convey "click this to get a list of users who read the message".
I like 4 if that's helpful! :)

Opened a WIP PR #18935 for read receipts to make sure I'm going in the right direction. It's just functional but a bunch of work is still left like:

  • Changing icon, for now, I just put R.
  • writing tests
  • cleaner UI for the read-by-users list.
  • adding any click functionality to the user list if needed.
    and probably more.

The next todo with this for me is to add an icon for show read receipts button. We seem to be liking 4. box-check from Alya Abbott's suggestions above.. How should I go about adding it? I see it's super simple to add a fontawesome icon but I'm not sure how to do it for a custom icon like that which would be consistent with our other buttons like add emoji reaction, star and others in .message_controls.

@Dinesh Ch for custom icons, if you add the SVG to static/assets/icons, it'll be available as an icon font like the bot.svg.

There's some documentation here: https://zulip.readthedocs.io/en/latest/subsystems/html-css.html#adding-static-files. If that doesn't make clear what you need to do, we should probably extend it :smile:

Thanks for the pointer!

I tried creating a replica of the box one shared by Alya Abbott. Does this look good? image.png (svg file: readreceipts512.svg )

A few similar variants:

  • 3-line version: image.png readreceipts-3lines512.svg
  • 2-line version: image.png readreceipts-2lines512.svg
fwiw idk if you knew this but fa supports icon stacking.. https://fontawesome.com/v5.15/how-to-use/on-the-web/styling/stacking-icons

I think the 2-line version works pretty well, and I like it the best of those.

The thing that feels like it's missing in the first version is that the rectangle is meant to suggest a message, and doesn't very clearly do so in that version. I figure that's probably why you tried adding the lines. That's a pretty reasonable way to try to do that. Another idea to try might be to make the rectangle a little wider and/or shorter.
Yeah, I think the two-line version looks pretty good. Size-wise, it should be a little smaller to match the smiley and the star.

Size-wise, it should be a little smaller to match the smiley and the star.

Does this look good in terms of size? image.png

(Will try a wider version as Greg suggested now, but I think it'll look odd with smiley and star being symmetrical or having square borders)

The wider and shorter version looks good too: image.png

aligned: image.png
The horizontal alignment seems a bit off.
You mean spacing between the icons?
The rest of the icons are center (middle) aligned while the read receipts icon seems to be bottom aligned.
I edited the message with an aligned one. Does it look right? I'm not sure how it works but increasing the height moved it a bit up.
Yep, looks better.

To keep this thread updated, the current status of read receipts: I think almost all the work on this is done. What's left is adding a setting to enable/disable sharing these for which there's another PR #19200 which should be fixed after we merge #19561. (Being able to merge those two would also let us integrate the typing indicator for streams PR #17040 with settings for that too.)

@shrizza every time you query it, it asks the server for the latest data; we don't live-sync reading activity at all, which greatly simplifies the implementation as well as being the most practical way to avoid scaling issues with large streams/organizations.
